entities.name: Bulldog
entities.description: The English Bulldog is typically friendly, loyal, and good with other pets and children. They are known to be calm and even lazy, serving as four-legged companions. Despite their reputation for being lazy, Bulldogs benefit from daily exercise. They typically don’t need a significant amount of exercise, but it can be helpful—especially in those that are overweight.

entities.name: Feeding Bulldogs
entities.description: Adult Bulldogs should be fed twice a day, in morning and evening. English Bulldog puppies need to eat more frequently (about three or four times daily). Some English Bulldogs may require a slow feeder bowl so they don’t eat too quickly, which can result in regurgitation or aspiration pneumonia.

entities.name: Bulldog Supplements
entities.description: There are many dog supplements that can help maintain the overall health of your Bulldog. These include Omega-3 fatty acids, joint supplements that contain glucosamine, probiotics, and immune-boosting supplements.

entities.name: Bulldog Grooming
entities.description: The English Bulldog has a short, smooth hair coat with a moderate shedding level. Their wrinkly skin requires frequent and time-consuming grooming. The skin wrinkles and folds around a Bulldog’s face, neck, and tail should be evaluated and cleaned daily.

entities.name: Bulldog Training
entities.description: Begin training and socializing your English Bulldog puppy as soon as you bring them home. Bulldogs respond best to positive reinforcement training. Treats should never make up more than 10% of your dog’s daily calorie intake.

entities.name: Bulldog Health Considerations
entities.description: Bulldogs have potential health issues, sensitivity to heat, weight management requirements, and grooming needs. These considerations are important because they can greatly affect the overall lifestyle of the English Bulldog. They may require lifelong medical care and may ultimately need surgical intervention or a referral to a specialist veterinarian to fully alleviate these medical issues.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: The Bulldog, commonly called the English Bulldog, is well known for their wide stance; muscular low profile; and short, wrinkled face with an underbite. They are short (at only 14–15 inches tall), weigh a sturdy 40–50 pounds, and have drooping lips with many loose skin wrinkles and folds throughout their face and neck.

entities.name: Brachycephalic Obstructive Airway Syndrome (BOAS)
entities.description: Bulldogs commonly have brachycephalic obstructive airway syndrome (BOAS). This condition is caused by a combination of anatomical abnormalities that can be present due to the breed’s flat face, including narrowed nose openings, elongated soft palate in the mouth, swelling in the larynx, and compressed/distorted nasal passages. This leads to difficulty breathing and a propensity to overheat.

entities.name: Skin Fold Pyoderma and Allergies
entities.description: The excessive skin wrinkles throughout a Bulldog’s face and neck can cause skin issues. Any time an English Bulldog gets wet, their wrinkles can trap moisture if they are not properly dried. The warm, moist environment provides the perfect habitat for bacteria and/or yeast growth—commonly referred to as skin fold pyoderma.

entities.name: Hip Dysplasia
entities.description: It’s extremely common for Bulldogs to develop hip dysplasia, a condition in which the hip joint does not function properly. Because the English Bulldog’s hip joints are elevated above shoulder height, the abnormal position causes the thigh bone (femur) to fit awkwardly in the pelvis at the hip joint.

entities.name: Entropion
entities.description: The English Bulldog can develop entropion, which is the inward rolling-in of the eyelids (usually the lower eyelids). This condition causes the outer hair of the eyelid to make contact with the surface of the eyeball. Entropion can irritate the eye, causing redness, pain, swelling, and discharge.

entities.name: Obesity
entities.description: The English Bulldog is prone to obesity, and the extra weight can exacerbate other health concerns. To help prevent unnecessary weight gain, be diligent about the type and amount of food you give your Bulldog.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: The Bulldog, commonly called the English Bulldog, is well known for their wide stance; muscular low profile; and short, wrinkled face with an underbite. They are short (at only 14–15 inches tall), weigh a sturdy 40–50 pounds, and have drooping lips with many loose skin wrinkles and folds throughout their face and neck.

entities.name: Brachycephalic Obstructive Airway Syndrome (BOAS)
entities.description: Bulldogs commonly have brachycephalic obstructive airway syndrome (BOAS). This condition is caused by a combination of anatomical abnormalities that can be present due to the breed’s flat face, including narrowed nose openings, elongated soft palate in the mouth, swelling in the larynx, and compressed/distorted nasal passages. This leads to difficulty breathing and a propensity to overheat.

entities.name: Skin Fold Pyoderma and Allergies
entities.description: The excessive skin wrinkles throughout a Bulldog’s face and neck can cause skin issues. Any time an English Bulldog gets wet, their wrinkles can trap moisture if they are not properly dried. The warm, moist environment provides the perfect habitat for bacteria and/or yeast growth—commonly referred to as skin fold pyoderma. Allergies also commonly affect Bulldogs, which can lead to skin infection and pyoderma as well.

entities.name: Hip Dysplasia
entities.description: It’s extremely common for Bulldogs to develop hip dysplasia, a condition in which the hip joint does not function properly. Because the English Bulldog’s hip joints are elevated above shoulder height, the abnormal position causes the thigh bone (femur) to fit awkwardly in the pelvis at the hip joint. This abnormal position creates an unstable hip joint, which can lead to arthritis and possible bone fractures over time.

entities.name: Entropion
entities.description: The English Bulldog can develop entropion, which is the inward rolling-in of the eyelids (usually the lower eyelids). This condition causes the outer hair of the eyelid to make contact with the surface of the eyeball. Entropion can irritate the eye, causing redness, pain, swelling, and discharge.

entities.name: Obesity
entities.description: The English Bulldog is prone to obesity, and the extra weight can exacerbate other health concerns. To help prevent unnecessary weight gain, be diligent about the type and amount of food you give your Bulldog.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: The English Bulldog is typically friendly, loyal, and good with other pets and children. They are known to be calm and even lazy, serving as four-legged companions. They have a short, smooth hair coat with a moderate shedding level and their coats can come in a wide range of colors and combinations. Their wrinkly skin requires frequent and time-consuming grooming.

entities.name: Feeding
entities.description: Adult Bulldogs should be fed twice a day, in the morning and evening. English Bulldog puppies need to eat more frequently, about three or four times daily. Some English Bulldogs may require a slow feeder bowl so they don’t eat too quickly, which can result in regurgitation or aspiration pneumonia.

entities.name: Exercise
entities.description: Despite their reputation for being lazy, Bulldogs benefit from daily exercise. They typically don’t need a significant amount of exercise, but it can be helpful—especially in those that are overweight. Bulldogs that are prone to or have been diagnosed with brachycephalic obstructive airway syndrome might not tolerate any exercise without having breathing issues.

entities.name: Training
entities.description: Bulldogs need to be well-trained and socialized to be confident and well-mannered. Bulldogs respond best to positive reinforcement training. Treats should never make up more than 10% of your dog’s daily calorie intake.

entities.name: Grooming
entities.description: The skin wrinkles and folds around a Bulldog’s face, neck, and tail should be evaluated and cleaned daily. English Bulldogs should be bathed once a week to every other week, with special attention given to their skin wrinkles/folds. Brushing your English Bulldog once a week with a soft bristle brush is recommended to help maintain a healthy coat.

entities.name: Health Considerations
entities.description: Because of their health considerations, there are many dog supplements that can help maintain the overall health of your Bulldog. These include Omega-3 fatty acids, joint supplements that contain glucosamine, probiotics, and immune-boosting supplements.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: The English Bulldog is typically friendly, loyal, and good with other pets and children. They are known to be calm and even lazy, serving as four-legged companions. They have a short, smooth hair coat with a moderate shedding level and their coats can come in a wide range of colors and combinations. Their wrinkly skin requires frequent and time-consuming grooming.

entities.name: Bulldog's Health Issues
entities.description: Bulldogs can be prone to health issues such as brachycephalic obstructive airway syndrome, eye issues, allergies, and skin infections. They may require lifelong medical care and may ultimately need surgical intervention or a referral to a specialist veterinarian to fully alleviate these medical issues.

entities.name: Bulldog's Weight Management
entities.description: Bulldogs require careful weight management due to their propensity for weight gain. Treats should never make up more than 10% of your dog’s daily calorie intake.

entities.description: Bulldogs require frequent and time-consuming grooming due to their wrinkly skin. Their skin wrinkles and folds around their face, neck, and tail should be evaluated and cleaned daily.
